Topic number two: The down-low phenomenon was revealed a few years ago as a black phenomenon with men secretly having sex with women and men, and was widely cited as a key reason for the increase of HIV infections among African-American women.
Now we are finding that that information might have been embellished just a little bit.
Research showing that black men living under those guiles and claiming to be straight while having sex with men in secret did, in fact, not increase the spread of HIV.
So Yvonne, how important is this revelation?

I think it's very important from the standpoint that it seems that when we deal with black Americans that we take a kernel of information, and rather than look and be clear about getting accurate facts, that we just run with assumptions.

In this case, anybody who had ever watched at daytime television show, whether it's back in the day Phil Donahue up until ""Oprah,"" knows that it's not just black men who are homosexual pretending to be heterosexual or at least engaging in heterosexual relations.
It's men across the board.
And that's nothing new.
There's certainly in more recent time been books.
Some of them, like E.
Lynn Harris and other writers who have discussed this in popular culture.
But to say that black men are any more disposed to doing this than white, Asian, Latino was off the mark from the very beginning.

So I think that it behooves scientists and the people who are seriously studying these issues to not just go with assumptions, not just go with ""20/20"" and what they're saying, to actually go and do the field research, do the science that is necessary to find real answers.
And I just think that we could continue to do a disservice by jumping along what the popular culture puts out there without doing the necessary real science work to get real answers.
